        shuffle=True,

        data_shape=(3,224,224),

http://mxnet.io/get_started/build_from_source.html

If you're on Ubuntu, good news is that these instructions are quite straightforward and should work as is (add openblas FLAG in config if using it for blas).

Thanks for the response. I'll do that
Re-run the code and it works.

CNN example: 
      - Image size=64x64 (without data augmentation) 
      - 3 Convolutional layers (num_filter= 16(first layer), 32(second layer), 64(third layer) and kernel=(3,3) for all ) +  fully connected layer(num_hidden=10)
      - SGD ( momentum )
      - mx.io.NDArrayIter for data iterator(  batch_size=50)
      - Training: model = mx.model.FeedForward.create(    ctx = mx.gpu(),   symbol=network,   num_epoch = 100,    X=train_iter, eval_data=val_iter,  learning_rate=0.0005, momentum=0.9 )

I tested the same network in Tensorflow, and these are the results:
                                                                                                  MxNet:       Validation-Accuracy=68.01 %
                                                                                                  Tensorflow: Validation Accuracy=74.06%

ResNet: 
      - Image size=64x64 (without data augmentation)  
      - 36 layers (1Convolution layer + 15 Residual-block + 1 fully connected layer).
      -  Residual-block (  BatchNorm+Activatin+Convolution+BatchNorm+Activation+Convolution). To increase the channels of Residual input to be as same size as its output I used the Convolution with kernel=(1,1).  The Mxnet Padding function in not working for 0 and 1 dimensions.
      - - mx.io.NDArrayIter for data iterator(  batch_size=50)
       - Training:  model = mx.model.FeedForward.create(  ctx = mx.gpu(),  symbol=network, num_epoch = 100,  optimizer = mx.optimizer.Adam(),  X=train_iter, eval_data=val_iter,  learning_rate=0.0005, momentum=0.9)

I also tested the same network in Tensorflow, and these are the results:
                                                                                                  MxNet:       Validation-Accuracy=71.45 %
                                                                                                  Tensorflow: Validation-Accuracy=82.5%
Tensorflow also shows  much more better performances with other configurations like larger image size and batch size. However Mxnet is saturated to 71%.

The capital letter is used to specify the layout of data, which is used in convolution usually:
N: batch size
C: channel
H: height
W: width
so that "NCHW" means a data whose layout is `(batch_size, channel, height, width)`

and the lower case `k` represents a enum class, see: https://github.com/dmlc/mshadow/blob/master/mshadow/base.h#L312
https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/include/mxnet/operator.h#L24
We need to document the behavior of layout.
Why "batch size" is  N, and "k" represents "a enum calss" ?
@kernel8liang just custom, which is also common in other librarys

I found this issue is related to `int MXExecutorFree(ExecutorHandle handle)`. A temporary workaround for me is to delay every `MXExecutorFree()` call by 200ms.

I wonder if it is because in `GraphExecutor::~GraphExecutor()`, the code forgot to ensure the operator have finished computing before we calling `Engine::Get()->DeleteOperator()`.

Do all databatch have 0 index? If so:

```
    def getindex(self):
        index_size = ctypes.c_uint64(0)
        index_data = ctypes.POINTER(ctypes.c_uint64)()
        check_call(_LIB.MXDataIterGetIndex(self.handle,
                                           ctypes.byref(index_data),
                                           ctypes.byref(index_size)))
        address = ctypes.addressof(index_data.contents)
        dbuffer = (ctypes.c_uint64* index_size.value).from_address(address)
        np_index = np.frombuffer(dbuffer, dtype=np.uint64)
        return np_index.copy()
```

You can try to print index information in MXDataIterGetIndex to see whether something is wrong.

So I got all cleaned up except a certain test-failure in roi-pooling. Though this is untouched by these changes here, except for using a newer version of mshadow. It seems that this problem is caused by a recent change on 4/4 (PR 227) which sets kMaxGridNum in tensor_gpu-inl.cuh to MaxInt. The current MxNet master version includes a prior version of mshadow so is not affected by this change. 
My code has to use the more recent mshadow. And in roi-pooling (and one other operator), kMaxGridnum is used in this expression:
dim3 dimGrid(kMaxGridNum, (gridSize + kMaxGridNum - 1) / kMaxGridNum);
which will may to integer overflows. Also dimGrid will be passed to CheckLaunchParam and this will anyway fail then as it expects the first dimension to be smaller than 2^16. 
Will try to fix this.
Any other suggestion?  I put comments about this into PR 227 in mshadow.

I suggest you use "https://cloud.r-project.org/" instead.

It's not memory leak, I used base_module.predict() API, which will keep all detection outputs copies in memory, that's why gpu memory is increasing. If you need to predict thousands of images, you can use iter_predict() function instead.
```
def detect(self, det_iter, show_timer=False):
        """
        detect all images in iterator

        Parameters:
        ----------
        det_iter : DetIter
            iterator for all testing images
        show_timer : Boolean
            whether to print out detection exec time

        Returns:
        ----------
        list of detection results
        """
        num_images = det_iter._size
        if not isinstance(det_iter, mx.io.PrefetchingIter):
            det_iter = mx.io.PrefetchingIter(det_iter)
        result = []
        for det in self.mod.iter_predict(det_iter):
            det = det[0][0][0].asnumpy()
            res = det[np.where(det[:, 0] >= 0)[0]]
            result.append(res)
        return result
```
Note that this is much slower than predict, because for each image, the result will be copied from gpu to cpu. It's up to you which one you'd like.

@kevinthesun could you change the css?

@sxjscience The original STN paper uses different localisation networks for each dataset. I don't see how the current localisation network can be _wrong_ since it basically gives the same results as lenet for vanilla mnist. 

If you want to use STNs with cluttered MNIST, then sure, you'll probably need/want another type of localisation network. 

However that doesn't change the fact that the current lenet-stn example code is a bit broken because (1) there are no command line arguments to set the add_stn parameter to True (2) if add_stn is set to True there is no get_loc function to create a localisation network and you'll get an error.

If having a STN in vanilla MNIST seems overkill because it doesn't give any apparent performance advantages and you want to remove the example altogether and add another example with cluttered MNIST that's ok, but I think that the example is useful because it shows how to add a STN layer with a simple model and dataset.

@DickJC123

From your error log: 

mxnet.base.MXNetError: [12:01:59] src/storage/./pooled_storage_manager.h:84: cudaMalloc failed: out of memory

The GPU memory is not enough

By Default MxNet network looks for an input with the name 'softmax_label' as the target variable for training. When you built your network by loading the check-point, it was expecting an input 'softmax_label' which you did not provide that hence the warning. 
Take a look here: 
https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/python/mxnet/module/module.py#L31

A probable remedy could be to just supply a dummy variable with the name 'softmax_label'
@precedenceguo We need to revise the launching parameter of ROIPooling.
